citation.article-title: Rhizobacter daucus gen. nov., sp. nov., the causal agent of carrot bacterial gall.

p.s: Description of Rhizobacter gen. nov.
(Rhi.zo.bacter. rhizo, root system; bacter, a rod; Rhizobacter, root rod)
Straight to slightly curved, nonsporeforming, encapsulated, gram-negative rods.
Motile with polar flagella or lateral flagella or both.
Poly-β-hydroxybutyrate granules are formed.
Chemoorganolrophic.
Aerobic with respiratory metabolism of glucose.
Utilizes D-glucose as a sole source of carbon and energy.
White or yellowish white, plicated, tough or viscid colonies on agar plates.
Floccular growth consisting of globular units iin liquid media; fingerlike projections never occur.
Positive for production of oxidase, catalase, and H2S from cysteine, nitrate reduction, the o-nitrophenyl-β-D-galactopyranoside test, and growth inhibition by KCN.
Negative for denitrification, the methyl red test, and production of arginine dihydrolase, nitrogenase, fluorescent pigment, indole, and acetoin.
Susceptible to 10 μg of vibriostatic agent O/129 phosphate.
Hydrolyzes starch, dextrin, and glycogen.
Cannot utilize benzene derivatives as carbon sources.
Does not require NaCl and growth factor.
Ubiquinone Q8.
Yellow pigment differs from xanthomonadins.
The G+C content of the DNA is 67 to 71 mol%.
The type species is Rhizobacter daucus Goto et Kuwata 1988.
